instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-02098: What is 820-02098? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.A2251: What is A2251? A2251 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2020 with EMC 3348, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01949..
definitions.A2289: What is A2289? A2289 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2020 with EMC 3456, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01987..
definitions.A2338: What is A2338? A2338 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2020 M1, Mid 2022 M2 with EMC 8162, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-02020, 820-02773..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard not typing, liquid dmg
threads.message:
Looking for a way to source a new chip for the UT101 spot. Above removal of the chip that was there it completely broke in half and fell apart (yes I know, throw tomatoes). The caps were all replaced with new caps now and all that is missing is the chip. [B]L16A030D215[/B] is what is written on it.  All other features with the computer work as intended. No random reboots, trackpad works, no throttling or lag. 

Any help or guidance would be great.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard not typing, liquid dmg
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

UT101/2 encrypt keyboard information and send it to trackpad, through I2C bus.
So need to replace UT101.
These chips have firmare, but probably work any from other M1 model.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard not typing, liquid dmg
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 100802, member: 682"]
First of all, welcome to the forum!

UT101/2 encrypt keyboard information and send it to trackpad, through I2C bus.
So need to replace UT101.
These chips have firmare, but probably work any from other M1 model.
[/QUOTE]
Hi there thank you for the welcome!

Is there somewhere I can get these chips aside from a donor board? And is the chip literally called UT101? 

I appreciate your help thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard not typing, liquid dmg
threads.message:
The chip code is PCAL6416A, in QFN package.
You can only get it from scrap boards.

Same chip is used in older Macs, like <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> and <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, but in BGA package; useless here.

You can find QFN package in other M1 model, like <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>.
It is also available on T2 models, like <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2251</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>.
Just open schematics and search in pdf for "PCAL64"; then (if found) be sure it is HWQFN package (not BGA).

BTW, write directly into reply box, instead of clicking Reply button.
I don't see any reason to quote an entire post, visible few centimeters above.
Please, maintain forum aesthetic.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard not typing, liquid dmg
threads.message: Thank you very much. I'll do just that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard not typing, liquid dmg
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard not typing, liquid dmg
threads.message:
For that price, you can try.
But not sure if has correct firmware loaded...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard not typing, liquid dmg
threads.message:
So unfortunately after soldering the chip on the keyboard still does not function. 

This is a personal device now so I'm not going to give up even if I have to be patient on a solution

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard not typing, liquid dmg
threads.message:
Check if both UT101/2 get correct power.
Also check voltage and diode mode at <SIGNAL>I2C_KBD_SCL</SIGNAL>/SDA.
Be sure RT110/1 are good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard not typing, liquid dmg
threads.message:
So I reflowed the chip and replaced a cap that wasn't showing ground and the keyboard is now functional.... except the return / enter key. Trying to look  through the boardview now, I see there are special call outs for Right Shift and Left Shift, but nothing that says "return" or "Enter". I feel like I'm very close.

Correction the Return, G, S, {,},| keys do not work. I tried a replacement keyboard and the same issue occurs. I'm wondering if this is a connector issue or something else.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard not typing, liquid dmg
threads.message:
When more keys are not woeking, very likely is a problem related with one row, or column of keyboard matrix.
Unfortunatelly, no keys distribution on the matrix available.
You should check all <SIGNAL>KBD_DRIVE</SIGNAL>/SENSE lines.
May have problems with JT200, or trace continuity until UT101/2.

BTW, for full test of keyboard, search on Google by "keyboard tester"; choose any one you like.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard not typing, liquid dmg
threads.message: I wanted to update you, I ended up reseating the chip again and made sure all pads made contact, and I'm happy to report that keyboard is completely functional now. Thank you very much for pointing me to the right direction.
